page.title: 05Earthworks At Cwm George
page.content: The history of the earthworks begins in the Iron Age Period, 5000 years ago. It was lightly fortified and consisted of an enclosure in a bluff, this being situated on a steep hill surrounded by four sets of inner banks and two sets of uncompleted outer banks. In the 1940s Mortimer Wheeler spent 4 years digging at the site and found that the main occupation was in the Dark Ages. Evidence suggests it was lightly defended in this period and the occupants led a cultured life, as manifest in their use of wine and olive oil. In the enclosure remains have been found of two buildings, possibly a great hall and a barn. During the 1100s the site was occupied by the Normans and was later occupied in Cromwell's time. The last owner was Iestyn Ap Gwrgan.
